title: From Benchmark Data To Applicable Program Repair: An Experience Report
data:
M Chandramohan, J Jancic, Y Zhang, P Krishnan\xc2\xa0- arXiv preprint arXiv:2508.16071, 2025
This paper describes our approach to automated program repair. We combine 
various techniques from the literature to achieve this. Our experiments show that our 
approach performs better than other techniques on standard benchmarks. However, 
on closer inspection, none of these techniques work on realistic defects that we see 
in industry. We find that augmenting code with formal specifications enables LLMs to 
generate higher-quality unit tests, especially for complex production code with\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\xa6
\xe2\x80\xa2

title: How Small is Enough? Empirical Evidence of Quantized Small Language Models for Automated Program Repair
data:
K Kusama, H Shu, M Kondo, Y Kamei\xc2\xa0- arXiv preprint arXiv:2508.16499, 2025

title: Data and Context Matter: Towards Generalizing AI-based Software Vulnerability Detection
data:
R Safdar, D Mateen, ST Ali, MU Ashfaq, W Hussain\xc2\xa0- arXiv preprint arXiv:2508.16625, 2025
The performance of AI-based software vulnerability detection systems is often limited 
by their poor generalization to unknown codebases. In this research, we explore the 
impact of data quality and model architecture on the generalizability of vulnerability\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\xa6
